trial_identification.studytitle: Impact of choice of feeding on DNA damage in 3-6 month old infants a pilot study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Impact of choice of feeding on DNA damage in 3-6 month old infants a pilot study

conditions.healthcondition: Diet and Nutrition .The aim of the study is to determine whether the choice of how an infant is fed affects their DNA and folate in the body.

interventions.interventions: The collection of a heel prick blood sample from infants when they at 3months of age and then when they are at 6 months of age.Completion of questionnaires relating to health and lifestyle of both the mother and child which includes the feeding regime of the infant will be done twice,when the child is 3 months of age and at 6 months of age.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine whether the choice of how an infant is fed affects their DNA and folate in the body.This will be done by collecting the heel prick blood sample from the infants and collecting a feeding and food questionnaire from the mother.The validated Cancer Council of Victoria Food frequency questionnaire will be used.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The mother and infant will attend one visit when the child is 3 months of age and one visit when they are 6 months of age.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy mothers and their infants,born at term or at least a minimum of 38 weeks gestation.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Infants of multiple parity,mothers who cannot understand the study protocol and are unable to give appropriate consent to all stages of the protocol and attend the clinic when the infant is approximately 3 months and 6 months of age.Infants who have been introduced to solid foods prior to 3months of age.

contact.name: Dr Nathan O'Callaghan
contact.address: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Kintore Ave Adelaide SA 5000
